an4.8:4.1: “Mendicants, a Realized One has four kinds of self-assurance. With these he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the holy wheel.
an4.8:4.3: I see no reason for anyone—whether ascetic, brahmin, god, Māra, or Brahmā, or anyone else in the world—to legitimately criticize me, saying: ‘You claim to be fully awakened, but you don’t understand these things.’
an4.8:4.4: Since I see no such reason, I live secure, fearless, and assured.
an4.8:5.1: I see no reason for anyone—whether ascetic, brahmin, god, Māra, or Brahmā, or anyone else in the world—to legitimately criticize me, saying: ‘You claim to have ended all defilements, but these defilements have not ended.’
an4.8:5.2: Since I see no such reason, I live secure, fearless, and assured.
an4.8:6.1: I see no reason for anyone—whether ascetic, brahmin, god, Māra, or Brahmā, or anyone else in the world—to legitimately criticize me, saying: ‘The acts that you say are obstructions are not really obstructions for the one who performs them.’
an4.8:6.2: Since I see no such reason, I live secure, fearless, and assured.
an4.8:7.1: I see no reason for anyone—whether ascetic, brahmin, god, Māra, or Brahmā, or anyone else in the world—to legitimately criticize me, saying: ‘Though you teach that this Dharma leads to the goal of the complete ending of suffering, it doesn’t lead there for one who practices it.’
an4.8:7.2: Since I see no such reason, I live secure, fearless, and assured.
an4.8:7.3: A Realized One has these four kinds of self-assurance. With these he claims the bull’s place, roars his lion’s roar in the assemblies, and turns the holy wheel.”
